fields.public_access_description:
Design for a tomb for Pope Leo X. It shows a statue of the pope reclining on the top of the monument; the allegorical figures of Hope, Love, Faith and Charity are below. A tablet in the middle is inscribed with the first ten letters of the alphabet and the name 'LEO X'.

The design was probably made by Sansovino in an attempt to obtain the commission for Leo X's tomb, perhaps in the Pope's lifetime, or soon after his death in 1521.

The drawing was part of the collection assembled by John Talman (1677-1726). Talman was the son of the celebrated architect William Talman. From about 1698 he was employed by his father to help assemble material for his extensive collection of architectural drawings, prints and books. A keen traveller, he went  to the Continent twice in search of acquisitions. He visited the northern Netherlands, France, Germany and Italy, and he made numerous watercolour copies of altarpieces and churches in Rome. 

Talman was back in England in 1715. He was a founder-member of the Tavern Society, London, which later became the Society of Antiquaries, and he was appointed its first director. Like his father, Talman believed in the elevating purpose of art and in the use of art collections for the public good. Although his will indicates that he had wanted his vast collection (which contained over 32,000 prints and drawings), to go to Trinity College, Cambridge, he later changed his mind and instructed that it should be sold for the benefit of his children. A portion of the collection was nonetheless given outright to the Society of Antiquaries, who acquired further items from the auction in London on 19 April 1727.

"Andrea Sansovino and the design for a funerary monument for Leo X". No. 1268, Vol. CL: November 2008, pp. 757-759. The following is an extract from the text of the article: (item 2260 is figure 49 in the article) The collection of the Gabinetto Disegni e Stampe of the Uffizi contains a considerable number of designs for funerary monuments dating from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries. About 190 drawings related to such monuments are noted by Pasquale Nerino Ferri in his Indice geografico analitico dei disegni degli Uffizi.1* There is no catalogue raisonné of these drawings and, while some have been discussed in monographic studies on individual artists, a considerable number of the sheets are still categorised as anonymous works. One of these sheets (Fig.48) is the subject of this article.2* Listed by Ferri in his Indice as 'Anonymous sixteenth century', the drawing, a fragment in a very bad state of conservation, has never been published before. Yet it matches the upper part of a drawing, a Design for a funerary monument for Leo X in the Victoria and Albert Museum, London (Fig-49), 3* attributed to Andrea Sansovino and dated to 1521 by Ulrich Middeldorf. 4* The two designs, identical in their form, style and architecture, are virtually on the same scale. Although it is mutilated and badly damaged, the Uffizi sheet has the freshness and freedom of execution of an original drawing rather than of a copy. In all probability we are dealing with two projects by Sansovino for the pope's tomb, one fragmentary but probably original; the other more intact but perhaps later. 5* As is well known, the sepulchral monuments of Leo X and Clement VII in S. Maria sopra Minerva, Rome, one of the great sculptural undertakings of the sixteenth century, were commissioned in March 1536 from Baccio Bandinelli. 6* The project recorded in the V. & A. drawing was never realised. The lower part of this ambitious study (it was evidently also present in the Uffizi sheet before it was cut) consists of a grandiose architectural base articulated by four pilasters surmounted by a frieze of metopes and triglyphs (in the Uffizi sheet only two metopes are indicated while in the V. & A. drawing metopes are indicated along the whole length of the frieze). In the V. & A. sheet a pair of allegorical female figures, probably representing Faith and Fortitude, appear on either side of a large central inscription: here Leo X's name appears preceded by the first nine letters of the alphabet. This type of inscription suggested to Middeldorf the possibility that this was not made as a result of an official commission for the project, but rather could have been made by Sansovino in the hope of obtaining the commission for the tomb while the pope was still alive or immediately after his death in 1521. 7* The sudden death of Leo X, on the other hand, occurred at a moment of religious and political crisis; the election to the papal throne of the pious and austere Hadrian VI in 1522 was an attempt to remedy the intrigues and factionalism in the Vatican and throughout Europe. In these circumstances, it would have been difficult to commission a grandiose monument to the memory of a Medici pope. It was only after the elevation of Clement VII, another Medici, to the pontificate in 1523 that it was deemed appropriate to erect a monument to Leo. In both drawings a pair of seated Virtues turn towards the sarcophagus at the apex of the monument. These figures have a strong affinity with the seated Virtues carved by Sansovino on the Monument of Cardinal Ascanio Sforza in S. Maria del Popolo, Rome, of 1505-07 (Fig.50)8* and, as Middeldorf noted,9* with Sansovino's drawing of Astronomy in the Uffizi. Finally, the figure of the deceased pope, semi-recumbent like an Etruscan tomb figure, can be compared to that in a drawing by Sansovino also in the V. & A., a design for a funerary monument for a cardinal (Fig. 51), 10* which shows the dead man wearing a mitre, leaning on his elbow and with his legs crossed. This particular position of the dead man, 11* defined by Valone 12* as 'between waking and sleeping', derives from ancient funerary art, both Etruscan and Roman. Interpreted in the light of a new philosophy of life and a new attitude to death, it seems to have been used for the first time in the cinquecento on Sansovino's two tombs in S. Maria del Popolo and subsequently became the standard form, from Sansovino's tomb of Cardinal Sant' Angelo in S. Marcello al Corso to Peruzzi's tomb of Hadrian VI in S. Maria dell' Anima. As Middeldorf noted, the London drawing constitutes a parting of the ways between a tomb type characteristic of the early Renaissance, indebted to medieval prototypes, in which there was a strong interdependence between architectural and sculptural elements, and the new type of funerary monument of the sixteenth century in which, as in Classical art, architecture and sculpture coexisted independently. The London design and the fragmentary sheet in the Uffizi constitute an important marker in the evolution of the forms of Renaissance funerary art. The effigy of the dead man assumes a new significance, tied to the cult of personality. Not many sixteenth-century tombs were commissioned by their patrons while they were still living and constructed under their supervision. The new role of the portrait, often, significantly, shown with open eyes, and the innovative, so-called 'Etruscan' pose of the body confer on the effigy the semblance of life and the hope of eternity. There, the pope's alert body is stretched out, his torso turned to the front while his face is bent forwards towards his hands.
